In October, when Mao refuted the formula of the “three directives as the axis,” he was not seeking full antagonism. Rather, he immediately made Deng an offer that tackled the crucial point, i.e., the evaluation of the Cultural Revolution. Mao proposed starting a broad public debate in order to evaluate thoroughly all the aspects of the preceding decade, starting with the negative ones, and asked Deng himself to lead a discussion on a national level. The proposal was obviously very difficult: it was divisive, but also very generous, and Mao repeatedly tried to persuade Deng to accept it. Mao was fully convinced that to open a public discussion of the Cultural Revolution was decisive. The Cultural Revolution had been, he said, basically, but not completely, good. Using a “classical” percentage, he said it had been “seventy percent positive,” but it had been thirty percent “inadequate” (有所不足). Of those events, he said, there were “very different points of view” (看法不见得一致). Also, among those who were not in favor, there were some who were simply “dissatisfied” (不满意) because they had been treated unfairly, and others, on the other hand, who wished “to settle accounts” (算帐) with the Cultural Revolution. It was time to discuss these issues openly: it was necessary to submit openly the evaluation of the Cultural Revolution to “research” (研究, the same term used when talking about research and “scholarly” study) in order to understand precisely what had been inadequate or insufficient (Mao, 1998b: 487–88). In short, Mao argued that it was time to explore primarily what had not worked in the Cultural Revolution.22

Mao proposed that Deng Xiaoping should assume the task of leading a work group created in the Central Committee to launch a national campaign of “research” into this crucial issue. He received a very clear rejection, which Deng reiterated on several occasions during the autumn of 1975. Deng replied he was not the right person for the job because he was not aware of events in which he had not participated from 1967. It was obviously a pretext, which put him in a very difficult position indeed. In refusing to assume the political leadership of “research” into the Cultural Revolution, Deng actually even renounced exerting any national political role, particularly when Mao so clearly distanced himself from his “General Program” and from the way he used his “directives as the axis.” Deng’s choice, however, was only apparently a renunciation. Although his firm rejection of Mao’s proposal in October 1975 involved a substantial limitation of his direct interventions for about a year (Deng was, however, very influential in all the events of 1976), his intransigence on this point in fact became the main element in his following success.

One may wonder what sort of mass debate there might have been in China at the end of 1975, that is to say a debate launched by Mao and directed by Deng about what was wrong with the Cultural Revolution, on the basis, moreover, of the previous campaign for the study of the theory of the dictatorship of the proletariat. This passage in the autumn of 1975 was undoubtedly crucial and also shows the extent of the alternatives in the Chinese political situation at the time, at least from Mao’s perspective. That Mao made an impossible invitation in order to put Deng in a tight spot should not be taken for granted. Mao repeated his invitation several times in October, and Deng’s official biographers, including his daughter, all reveal some surprise when reporting how resolutely Deng refused it.

Deng was certainly one of those who wanted to “settle accounts” with the Cultural Revolution, yet there were also many other leaders of the CCP that wanted to do the same but did not know how. The sense of Deng’s move—his stubbornness and in particular its effectiveness—should be seen within the context of the whole political situation in 1975. Deng could have exerted an enormous influence as chairman of a commission of the Central Committee to lead a movement of national study on the mistakes and shortcomings of the Cultural Revolution. Deng, however, was in no way interested in a political rethinking of the Cultural Revolution. Rather, considering his subsequent strategy, it became clear that the prohibition of any political rethinking of the Cultural Revolution was for Deng the fundamental condition for restoring state order. What he indicated, even running the risk of immediate failure, was to clear the way for what became the “thorough negation.” This third step of Deng’s in October 1975 was thus essential for all his future strategy.

Deng’s position immediately became weaker, and in the last months of the year every single previous initiative ceased completely, including the “Political Research Office.” In the following spring, Deng was “overthrown” again, but this second fall was brief. In October 1976, exactly one month after the death of Mao, after a small Thermidor during which the Maoist leaders on the Central Committee were arrested, the “thorough negation” of the Cultural Revolution began, becoming the basic formula on which the “new Chinese order” was built. In China, the whole period from October 1975 to October 1976 was marked by very strong political tensions, which remain to be analyzed in depth, especially as far as ideological disputes are concerned. The role of the university after the Cultural Revolution was, for example, a crucial topic. However, during that same year Deng wielded an important, though indirect, influence.23 The dispute with Mao ended in the autumn. In the months that followed, the political situation was not shaped by Deng’s statements and initiatives. What he said and did in 1975, however, remains essential to all that followed and laid the foundation for the coalition that still heads the party-state in China.

sec.title: The “Thorough Negation”
sec.p: Let us briefly recapitulate. In 1975, Deng Xiaoping based his comeback neither on a preconceived plan nor on the extension of his position before 1966, but on a succession of moves, each of which was made as an exact reply to the development of the political situation that had begun with Mao’s theses at the end of 1974. This does not mean that his success was accidental. The “reactive” nature of Deng’s subjective position produced a coherent and extremely effective strategy.24 His refusal to lead a national debate on the “inadequacies” of the Cultural Revolution in October was the direct consequence of policies that had started with the zhengdun in the spring and continued with the “three directives as the axis” in the summer.

In each of these three stages, Deng was unbending in declaring the theoretical debates and political experimentations that Mao was promoting in those months not only worthless but also dangerous sources of disorder. The targets of Deng’s initiative continued and changed according to developments in the situation itself. Initially it was a “symptomatic” reaction which, if isolated, would have been ineffective. Deng repeated throughout the spring how important it was to tackle “disorder,” while never mentioning the true root of the problem, which was definitely not “factionalism” but the views expressed by Mao at the end of December 1974. In a second step, given that Mao’s “metaphysical” theses were gaining an influence that could no longer be ignored, Deng changed his mind and indicated “putting in order” those theses, but this time he found an obstacle in Mao himself. Mao, in turn, made a move clarifying that what was at stake was the evaluation of the Cultural Revolution. On this point the differences between them became irreconcilable. Deng was in no way interested in politically rethinking the Cultural Revolution: he simply wanted to “thoroughly deny it.”

However, this “denial” could not be truly “thorough.” In order to be effective, it had to necessarily incorporate some essential elements of discontinuity that the Cultural Revolution had introduced compared to the old order. In other words, Deng acted effectively because he clearly understood what the one key point in that necessary break could only be, taking it from both the Cultural Revolution, particularly the January Storm, and from the 1975 political situation. Deng said he did not know much of what had happened during the Cultural Revolution, but he said this to avoid what would otherwise have become a serious obstacle to any of his eventually successful strategy. In fact, Deng was very familiar with, and considered very carefully, the Cultural Revolution and, despite the official formula, his politics were based on a “selective negation.” By taking from the Cultural Revolution only those decisive elements of the “destruction” of the previous ideology and organization, and at the same time rejecting all forms of “construction” in terms of political experimentations, it became possible for Deng to restore state order in China.

First of all, Deng understood that the previous relationship between the “working class” and the “party-state” was the point that had undergone the most radical destabilization in the Chinese socialist system. As we have said, the entire edifice of the socialist state was founded on the inclusion of the political figure of the worker in the state. The Cultural Revolution, particularly the events in the autumn–winter of 1966–1967 in Shanghai, with the radical questioning of the political value of the relationship between the worker and the industrial danwei, had dismantled a key point in the epistemic network and, at the same time, in the state consistency based on the conceptual chain of “worker–factory–class–party–state.” In tackling that irreversible break, two courses were opened up: the first was experimentation with a new political consistency in the socialist factory with schemes such as the “workers’ university” and the “theoretical group”; the second, pursued by Deng with the utmost determination, was to radically depoliticize the worker–factory relationship, reducing it to a technical–disciplinary one.

However, the decisive move to depoliticize the industrial danwei could not be primarily a showdown with the Cultural Revolution in general. What Deng realized in 1975 was that the depoliticization of the socialist factory was a prerequisite for maintaining state order and that this could never be achieved without going through the denial of all attempts to re-politicize the factory that were underway at that time. Moreover, he would never have achieved his goal without believing in the importance of the reconsideration, which was taking place in those months, of the political categories that supported the state as based on the existence of a “proletariat.” Deng considered them to be merely a factor of permanent instability and appealed to the whole apparatus to react against a foreign body that had to be eliminated quickly before a catastrophic destruction of the state order occurred.

Deng would never have succeeded in his task without rejecting, step by step, all the novelty and the singularity of the 1975 political situation. The end of workers’ universities and the theoretical groups, and the repudiation of the whole “movement for the study of the theory,” were decided immediately after Hua Guofeng’s Termidorian coup d’état in October 1976, long before Deng’s return to the scene. This is a clear sign that Deng had formed a determined coalition to eradicate that “metaphysical disorder” in 1975, and that they had acted in full accordance with his ideas, even in his temporary absence. As is always the case, the Chinese Thermidorians, or at least those who merely wanted to eliminate the “excesses,” were in their turn also removed after a few years.

The wager Deng won was the reconstitution of a “socialist order” that would not depend on the inclusion of the political figure of the workers in the state, although even today the constitution of the Chinese Communist Party still declares that the CCP is the “vanguard of the proletariat.” One of Deng’s achievements was also maintaining the formulas of the old political language as a mere state ritual while depriving them of their concepts. Conversely, the Maoists’ weakest point at the end of the decade of the Cultural Revolution, far from being the “disorder” described by the winners, was the hope that those political experiments for reinventing the political value of the worker might not only be carried out within the framework of the party-state, but also that they could be a factor of political regeneration and even of stabilization. Deng decided, on the other hand, that he could reconstitute a state order only by eliminating the problem of how to seek a political essence of the worker, which for him was empty sophism.

The decade of the Cultural Revolution, briefly, marked the beginning of an irreversible crisis in the political existence of party-states, which then spread throughout the world, bearing consequences that have lasted up to the current crisis in contemporary state systems. For more than three decades, Deng’s turning point ensured China a stability of institutions far exceeding that of many other state systems, not to mention those socialist countries and communist parties around the world that collapsed. One of the factors behind China’s stability was certainly Deng’s ability to anticipate an epochal crisis in the forms of the state. However, the decisive factor in his success was the elimination from the political scene of the figure of the worker, after the rejection of that singular political moment represented by 1975 in China. In so doing, Deng launched a worldwide trend (called “neoliberalism”) which created a temporary stabilization of the state but which was in fact merely apparent, that is to say it actually produced a far more severe instability than the “disorder” Deng had initially wanted to tackle.

In the recent voluminous biography by Ezra Vogel, only one chapter (30 pages) out of twenty-four deals with the pre-1969 Deng Xiaoping. This disproportion, perhaps excessive, is indicative, however, of the radical difference in Deng’s post–Cultural Revolution political experience (Vogel, 2011).

The biographies of the main protagonists give other interesting elements, though strictly following the judgment of the Chinese government on the events. See Feng and Jin, 2003; Mao Mao [Deng Rong], 2000; Liu, 2006. The biography by Ezra Vogel in the chapters concerning 1975 basically follows Cheng and Xia, 2004, and Mao Mao, 2000 (see Vogel, 2011: 91–156).

Zhang Chunqiao, in presenting the 1975 constitution, had specified that the issue of the “freedom to strike” was “added as Chairman Mao’s proposal” (Zhang, 1975a: 18). Mao had been very active in the development of the first constitution of the People’s Republic of China in 1954. Note that the freedom to strike was stricken from the following constitution.

For the full text of Mao’s theses on the “study of theory,” see Mao, 1998a: 413–15. These theories had been initially set forth by Mao in December 1974 in a “theoretical seminar” held in the presence of Zhou Enlai, presumably as part of the preparatory meetings for the Fourth National Congress. Meetings for theoretical study at the top of the party were part of a tradition that dates back to the years of the War of Liberation and to some extent still remains today. Zhou Enlai personally arranged the circulation of the transcript of the interview, first in the central structures of the party and then in the press. Mao’s choice of Zhou Enlai as the first interlocutor of those theoretical issues is a sign of the close relationship between the two, which lasted until the end. However, since late 1973 and throughout 1974 Mao had various disagreements with Zhou Enlai with regard to foreign policy, which cannot be dealt with here.

In Vogel’s biography, Mao’s theses and the following “movement for the study of the theory of the dictatorship of the proletariat” do not play any significant role in the scene of 1975, which is fully occupied by a struggle between a Mao “mercurial” and “paranoid” and a Deng firmly committed to “restoring order.” However, as I will discuss below, denying that Mao’s theoretical theses had any value, or merely paying them lip service, was part of Deng’s deliberate political behavior on that scene. In this case, Deng’s alleged pragmatic lack of interest in “ideological” issues should not be taken too literally. Without paying close attention to Mao’s theses in 1975, and elaborating a series of specific moves for responding them, Deng would have never been able to build any winning strategy.

The article that launched the campaign and published Mao’s theses for the first time was an editorial in the People’s Daily (Renmin ribao shelun, 1975). Mao, who was very active in leading this theoretical movement, closely monitored the publication of a series of texts that relaunched his positions. Among them was an essay by Yao Wenyuan (Yao, 1975) and another by Zhang Chunqiao, cited above (Zhang, 1975b). Great emphasis was also placed on the publication of a selection of excerpts from texts by Marx, Engels, and Lenin that summed up the “classical” references (see Renmin ribao, Hongqi zazhi bianzhe, 1975). In this selection Stalin is evidently missing.
It is noteworthy that the first sociological research carried out by American scholars on the danwei was conducted in a hospital, not in a factory. See Henderson and Cohen, 1984.

The best firsthand narrative of the Shanghai events is Hunter, 1969. The memoirs of Shanghai’s mayor during the decade of the Cultural Revolution were published some years ago. See Xu, 2003. The only two global studies on this subject are Li, 1996; and Perry and Li, 1997.

Sylvain Lazarus has noted that the events of Shanghai in 1966–1967 started a global crisis over the question of the value of the category of the “working class,” a crisis that reached its apex in the late 1970s with the Polish Solidarność movement, after the 1969 Italian “autunno caldo” (hot autumn) and the rebellions of French workers in the late 1960s and early 1970s. See Lazarus, 1992; Lazarus, 1993. Wang Hui has rightly noted that in the early nineties the collapse of the Soviet Union was accompanied by the loss of peasants’ and workers’ “dignity” (尊严感), even if it had always been precarious, as seen in the political struggles of the twentieth century (Wang, 2010: 371–81). The issue of the political worth of workers and peasants has been central in the entire Chinese revolutionary politics. I would add that the origin of the contemporary annihilation of the political dignity of workers and peasants has to be sought in the very conclusion of the Chinese political events of the 1960s and 1970s.

The memoirs published by his daughter, Deng Rong (Mao Mao, 2000), show that after 1966 Deng Xiaoping was not particularly oppressed, nor jailed; on the contrary, he was carefully protected by both Mao and Zhou Enlai in view of a possible return to government. Since 1967 Mao himself suggested this possibility. From 1969 to 1972 Deng was sent to an agricultural district in Jiangxi, where he lived with his family and took part in manual work in a factory. His living conditions were quite proportionate to his ranking. From this village he kept up relationships with the government and with the party center.

In 1973 his main task was participating in a U.N. session where he gave a speech that confirmed the key positions of Chinese foreign policy in those years, namely the theory of the “three worlds” and China’s membership in the “Third World.”

It is meaningful that the official publication of the writings of Deng Xiaoping in the 1980s started with a volume covering the years from 1975 to 1981 (Deng, 1983). The volume covering the years before 1966 appeared only later.

I use depoliticization in a very different sense from Carl Schmitt. For him it means the lack of “the political,” that is the disappearance of the opposition amicus/hostis. For me egalitarian politics involves a series of subjective inventions and organizational experiments that go beyond that opposition. The depoliticization carried out by Deng concerned the full rejection of the Cultural Revolution. The ban, which is still in force in China, on reflecting on the Cultural Revolution is a condition of state consistency today. I have outlined some working hypotheses on this issue in Russo, 2006. On this issue I share many of Wang Hui’s analyses (Wang, 2008).

Zhengdun appears in the titles of five of the eight 1975 texts, from the first, “The army must be put in order,” to the last, “Everything must be put in order in every field.” See Deng, 1975a; Deng, 1975d. These texts come from speeches at meetings and conferences held in the central bodies of the army, the party, and the government. Ezra Vogel renders zhengdun as “consolidation” (Vogel, 2011: 96), which obliterates the disciplinary connotation of the term.

These data are cited in Cheng and Xia, 2004: 590. The data referring to 1975 economic growth are quite different but equally very positive in Feng and Jin, 2003: 1752 (GDP 8.7 percent; industry, 15.1 percent; agriculture, 3.1 percent).
I am grateful to Cui Zhiyuan, Professor of Public Policy and Management at Qinghua University, for having discussed these data with me.

Even in the early years of the Cultural Revolution, what is usually defined as “factionalism” really concerns different kinds of phenomena. For example, the fighting in Shanghai toward the end of 1966 between groups of workers called “Rebel Revolutionaries” and “Scarlet Guards,” which had the recognition of independent workers’ organizations at stake, had different content from the clashes that from the middle of 1967 increasingly saw opposing student organizations from different universities, leading to armed struggle between “factions” opposing each other over the largely imaginary issue of the “seizure of power.” These clashes, which increasingly became brawls between groups fighting for bureaucratic supremacy on the campuses, led to the political self-destruction of the student organizations themselves. After the second half of 1968, with the dissolution of the Red Guard student groups, the clashes ended, but the universities had almost no students until 1972–1973. The situation in the factories was quite different. In Shanghai the disputes between the groups of workers were particularly intense in December 1966 and January 1967, but the city later became a quite peaceful place so that it was an important center for political experimentation from the end of the sixties. I have analyzed the student factions during the first two years of the Cultural Revolution in the above mentioned essays, particularly in Russo, 2006. The most interesting sociological overview of those events is still the one carried out some years ago by Lynn T. White III (White, 1989; White, 1991). White argues that the violence that erupted between opposing groups during the Cultural Revolution had its roots in the structure of “state policies” that had become merely forms of social discipline, such as the use of categories like “class” or “good political behavior.” The analytic perspective I have proposed is very different from White’s, but I share the idea that the organizational structure of the Chinese state in those years lay at the root of factionalism: those students and their new independent political organizations after a few months of political vitality completely failed to break down that scheme. In a couple of years their political novelty had evaporated. In short, I believe the factionalism of 1967–1968, far from being a result of excessive politicization, was actually an effect of the “depoliticization” exercised by the bureaucratic model of socialist state. A limitation of recent analyses of Red Guard organizations (Walder, 2009; Andreas, 2009) is in my opinion the failure to distinguish the early disputes of the second half of 1966, which, also among students, had the issue of the political self-organization at stake, and the brawls of 1967–1968, whose major content was merely how to annihilate opposing “factions.” These analyses are in fact much more convincing for the latter moment. The situation in 1975 was in any case very different from the “factionalism” in 1967–1968.
Cited in Cheng and Xia, 2004: 539. Many new members were admitted into the party in 1974.

Deng was particularly severe with the “heads of factions” (头头). They had to be isolated by “cutting off their internal and external links” and “moved to other units.” If they refused to leave, they had to have “their salary suspended”: “If your job is to create factional unrest, why do you come to us to get a salary?” (Deng, 1975b: 6).
For the precise sense of this oxymoron, I refer to the above-quoted essay by Alain Badiou on “metaphysics” and the “critique of metaphysics” (Badiou, 2000).

“论全党全国各项工作的总纲,” October 7, 1975 (reprinted in Zhongguo renmin jiefangjun, 1988: 507–17). Two other documents, which I cannot discuss here, were on industry and scientific research: “关于加快工业发展的若干问题. 讨论稿” (Some Problems Concerning the Acceleration of Industrial Development. Draft for Discussion), September 2, 1975 (Zhongguo renmin jiefangjun, 1988: 487–97); “关于科技工作的几个问题” (Some Problems on Scientific and Technological Work), August 11, 1975 (Zhongguo renmin jiefangjun, 1988: 528–31). At the time none of these “programs” was officially published in the press, due to the fact that Deng’s political initiative ended in October 1975. In the following weeks, however, there were widespread editions for “internal use” (i.e., not directly available in the official press or in bookshops but distributed only within the “working units”), and these were later reprinted in early 1976 as appendixes to three separate volumes of criticism on Deng Xiaoping’s three programs.

Vogel narrates this crucial moment as the result of Mao’s determination to force Deng into giving a positive evaluation of the Cultural Revolution (Vogel, 2011: 145–51). This certainly fits into the current image, but the available documents show rather that Mao was really interested in a critical reflection on the mistakes of Cultural Revolution, while Deng was definitely hostile. It is true, however, as Vogel notes, that if Deng would have accepted in that moment to discuss, even critically, the Cultural Revolution, his following strategy based on the “thorough negation” would have been impossible.
He only returned to the scene in the early months of 1977 and quickly became the undisputed leader of the new course. His definitive return came in the following year.

Alain Badiou undertakes a detailed philosophical analysis of the logic of the “reactive subject” in the first part of Logiques des mondes (Badiou, 2006). The issue that I am most interested in examining is the role of reactive subjectivity in the relationship between political events and short-term forms of the state in modern times. In China the shift from the Cultural Revolution to “market socialism” is certainly full of issues of this kind. This research perspective is outlined in Pozzana and Russo, 2006; and Pozzana and Russo, 2011.

bio.title: Author Biography
bio.p: Alessandro Russo is an associate professor of sociology at the University of Bologna and has been visiting professor at the University of Washington and at Qinghua University. He has published various essays on contemporary Chinese politics and ideology and has finished a manuscript on the initial scene of the Cultural Revolution.
